Award.AwardTitle: NRI: Achieving Selective Kinematics and Stiffness in Flexible Robotics

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This research project will employ an effect called laminar jamming to create robotic structures that controllably transition between highly compliant and nearly rigid. Precise position control typically requires rigidity, while safe and comfortable interactions with humans requires compliance. The need to incorporate both characteristics arises, for example, in assistive applications such as tremor suppression in Parkinson's disease. It is also necessary for robots working collaboratively with humans in manufacturing settings. Laminar jamming structures are composed of multiple parallel layers that ordinarily slide easily over each other. However, when the laminar structure is squeezed the layers become locked together by friction forces. This project will derive computationally tractable models of laminar structures under external forcing, to enable parametric design and real-time control. Fabrication of laminar jamming devices is simple and inexpensive, lowering barriers to widespread use, both in commercial applications and in educational settings. To ensure dissemination of the results, reference designs, configurations of jamming elements, application prototypes, and testing and performance data will be posted on a popular soft robotics website.

The combination of laminar jamming and soft robotics opens an entirely new range of robot designs and behaviors. Because the bending stiffness of a beam is proportional to the third power of its thickness, even a few laminae can produce dramatic increases in stiffness when jammed. The goal of this project is to define the capabilities of the technology and derive and validate the fundamental underlying principles. The project consists of three research subtasks: actuator design and testing, computational and analytical modeling, and implementation of key applications. The results of the project will provide a rich set of building blocks for robots that combine the advantageous features of both soft and rigid robots.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Outcome Report

 

Jamming is a structural phenomenon that provides tunable mechanical behavior. A jamming structure typically consists of a collection of elements with a low effective stiffness and damping. When a pressure gradient, such as vacuum, is applied, the coupling between the elements increase, resulting in dramatically altered mechanical properties. Engineers have used jamming to build devices from tunable-stiffness grippers to tunable-damping landing gear. 

 

This project started by developing a thorough theoretical analysis of layer jamming structures? behavior, supported by both finite element simulations and experiments. Novel high-performing sandwich-based layer jamming structures were then introduced, enhancing the performance of traditional layer jamming structures. This novel design, with high-stiffness face layers and low-stiffness core layers, allows a 550-fold increase in stiffness-to-mass ratio, while achieving a rapid and reversible 1800-fold increase in stiffness. The analytical modeling of these sandwich jamming structures were also used to create an optimization algorithm, which allows designers to find the highest performing jamming structure given their system?s design constraints .  

 

Other than layers, elements of varying geometries have been used in jamming structures (e.g. grains and fibers). This project realized the first global comparative analysis of these different types of jamming structures, providing a framework that systematically guides the design of jamming structures for target applications. It identified high performing pairs (e.g., grains in compression, layers in bending). Parameters which go into designing, fabricating and actuating a jamming structure (e.g., scale, material, geometry, actuator) were described, along with their effects on functional metrics. Two key methods to expand on the design space of jamming structures were introduced: using structural design to achieve effective tunable-stiffness behavior in specific loading directions, and creating hybrid jamming structures to utilize the advantages of different types of jamming.

 

A collection of novel jamming-based structures were introduced throughout the project. These include: soft robot fingers with disappearing/appearing joints, a wrist orthosis, a variable stiffness endoscope, a mold-making sleeve and a robot joint with active stiffness control in specified degrees of freedom.  

 

This project contributed novel variable stiffness structures which allow for more versatile and high-performance soft robots. It also provided a large variety of design and analysis tools and frameworks which can be utilized by engineers, roboticists and designers when they're creating variable stiffness structures for their applications. By taking a comprehensive approach to all types of jamming structures which have been used in a wide variety of scales and applications, this project also was able to identify the empirical and theoretical gaps in the literature on jamming which is a contribution not only to the robotics, mechanical engineering and material science communities but also to the physics community. 

 

The broader impacts of this project have been multifaceted. First of all, versatile and high-performing variable stiffness robotic structures allow for a bridge between the two major paradigms in robotics: soft robots and rigid robots. This allows for robotic systems which can be both fast, strong and precise but also conformable, adaptable and safe. Within the context of variable stiffness structures, jamming structures have a particularly broader impact, since they are easily scalable, easy-to-fabricate, low-cost and relatively agnostic to material. Jamming structures, which can be fabricated just with some sheets of paper and a plastic bag, are highly accessible, as they can be fabricated in low resourced environments. In order to take advantage of this, we have made our design and fabrication guidelines accessible on an open source platform (softroboticstoolkit.com/laminar-jamming). We have organized multiple workshops with K-12 students, where they either designed and built their own jamming structures or they worked with existing structures to compare their performance. We have also utilized jamming structures in the context of sculptural installations. By incorporating variable stiffness to interactive art installations, we have experimented with how viewers can touch, feel and observe changes in stiffness and how that influences their art experience. 

 

Collectively, this project elaborated and extended the jamming design space, provided a conceptual modeling framework for jamming-based structures, and established a foundation for developing inverse design methodologies for jamming structures. Its practices also reached beyond the scientific community by engaging in K-12 outreach and visual arts.
